142013228.review:
A cute little stealth game where you play as an anthropomorphic cat named Kat, who is trying to collect gems in a base of the Dogo Corps headquarters and discover the dastardly leader's, Major Bulls', master plan. Cat Burglar is a short, light-hearted, stealthy puzzle platformer with a pet charity awareness campaign, each time you complete a level you are shown a different animal related charity.

The game has a cute 3D artstyle and fun gameplay. Some of the levels are rather tricky at certain times, but it's mostly rather relaxed and easy. The soundtrack is lovely and doesn't get annoying while playing. There is also extra challenge levels called Gem Jam mode and DOGO mode.

Gem Jam requires you to collect as many gems as you can before the timer runs out, that mode doesn't have any Dogo guards, so you are just focused on collecting the gems. DOGO mode has extra Dogo guards that you need to avoid, you don't collect any gems in this mode, but you need to find all 4 keys and get out of the level without the Dogo guards noticing you. Both modes add some extra fun to the game, but Gem Jam was a tad bit annoying, as the timer was short and achieving platinum in each level was hard.

For a free game this is definitely one of the more greater finds that I have found and it's definitely worth your time. Absolutely fantastic little game.

117017649.review:
A cute, little stealth game where you play as an anthropomorphic cat named Kat, trying to steal gems from equally anthropomorphic dogs. Mostly easy, but does have a bit of challenge to it as well. Can be played with keyboard and mouse, but controller is definitely preferable and easier, as you get full 360 degree movement and control over your speed. (I tried both.)

The gameplay consists of controlling Kat to sneak past the dog guards and grab four keys and as many gems as possible on the way, then make it to the locked vault, which ends the level. Kat must avoid touching the dog guards or their flashlight beams, and also avoid search lights that move in circular patterns. You also need to position the camera right to be able to see where you're going, and keys and gems to pick up.

The seven original levels are reworked for two other game modes: 
- In Gem Jam, all the guards and search lights have been removed from the levels, and lots of gems have been placed around the map. You have 1 minute to collect as many gems as possible, earning a higher medal reward the more you're able to collect. This was really fun, but also super easy. I definitely think the Platinum medal could've been at 200 gems instead of 150, because I found that I always had more than enough time to get that many on my first try. On some of the levels I was even able to collect every gem available, and still have time to spare. (Ending the level when there are no more gems left to collect would be nice, because I sometimes had to wait for the level to end.) I also think that these are a bit achievement spammy, basically netting you 4 achievements on each level. But the Gem Jam game mode was fun to play!
- In Dogo Mode, there are no longer any gems to collect. You only need to get the four keys and reach the vault. However, there are now a whole lot more dog guards around, and some of the paths have been removed. This is definitely a bit of a challenge compared to the normal game mode, but not much more challenging than if you're also going for all the gems in normal mode.

A couple of other things that I feel could be changed:
- Dog guards have light beams from their flashlights, and this can go through walls. If you're touched by it, you're automatically seen by the dog guard, even if there's a two feet thick steel wall between you. This isn't a big problem, as there are very few places this can happen, but it would be nice if there were none.
- Search lights can also see you even if you're not actually in the light. This might be that the collision box for Kat is a bit wider than her character model, and sometimes the lights hit it, and you must restart the level. Again, this one's not a big problem either, but as with the previous point it does feel annoying and unfair when it happens.
- The overlays for Gem Jam and Dogo Mode that appears at the start of the levels for those two game modes stay there too long, and it gets kind of annoying when you just want to retry a level after getting caught. For Gem Jam this is particularly annoying due to the extra "Ready?" and "Go!" overlays that you also need to wait for, while for Dogo Mode it's extra annoying because you're likely to get caught a few times per level, and will have to wait for the overlay every time.

The graphics are nice and fitting. Nothing big, but it works. The music feels kind of perfect for the game. Level design is decent. And mentioning them between levels is a nice way of spreading awareness for the various charities.

All in all, definitely worth playing!

100% in roughly 6 hours. (Most achievements are for just completing levels, some are for exploring the Extras menu, and one is for getting caught the first time. The only, slightly challenging achievements, aside from completing the more challenging levels, are getting all the gems in each of the seven normal missions.)

113114440.review:
I'd like to recommend Cat Burglar but a couple of big issues prevent this despite it being free.

Visually the game is appealing, I particularly like the character design of the dogs. There are seven maps with three play modes on each, stealth, timed crystal collection, and hard stealth. The time limit on the crystal mode is unfairly tight and should be adjusted.

The main stealth modes are fundamentally flawed in terms of the level design in relation to the camera setup.
Foreground objects often obstruct or even block your view completely(leaving you unable to see anything other than the shadow render of your character), you can't see the dogs, you can't see the floor layout and no amount of tinkering with the camera will fix this in certain parts of some stages.
When this happens your only real option is to find a spot where you can see and memorise the routine of the guards along the path you need to take then play it blind and hope the dog's torch is where you thought it was...

It froze my system on numerous occasions with logging out/in to windows via Ctrl+Alt+Del being the only fix.
Cat Burglar also makes you view a charity ad before beginning the first mode on all seven of it's stages.

If they alter the camera mechanics to make foreground objects(that obstruct the game play) transparent then I might rethink my opinion, until then I would advise against downloading it...

92272829.review:
[h1]A good game for testing the patience and spatiality of kids of all ages[/h1]
This game is cute, good-looking and with well-designed levels, with difficulty ramping up nicely.

You control the camera independently of the character, and you'll need to, to manage a nice mechanic of the game; navigating inside a building, moving the camera to where you can see what you're doing; finding gems and avoiding getting caught. So, as it says on the tin; it's a 3D puzzle platformer. That's the "[b]spatial[/b]" aspect.

The "[b]patience[/b]" aspect covers that you need to be methodical and scope out how the enemy guards will move, and how you will "solve" the next section.
There is one unfortunate design decision, though; if you get caught, you restart the level with all the keys (and gems) back in their place. So you need to start over from scratch, which can be taxing if you make just a small mistake. And completionists need to pick up all gems again.

But overall a nice experience, and the price is unbeatable (notice that you can chip in a few bucks by buying the DLC to support the devs and the cause).

74325348.review:
Cute cat creeping confounds canines for charity.

Cat Burglar: A Tail of Purrsuit is what it says on the cat-food tin, short and light-hearted. More specifically, it has 7 main levels of standard stealth/puzzle gameplay which should last you 1 to 2 hours. Now it also comes with two more game modes: Gem Jam (collect as many as you can); and Dogos (no collection, just pure stealthing through levels packed with dogs). Both of these are more difficult, and add up to 21 different levels, and can add many more hours of gameplay if you like a cute stealthy challenge.

The third-person view is a little wonky, as you can see your own character's outline through terrain, but it blocks your view of the dog guards, which can lead to a game over. Fortunately the levels are short and quick enough that this doesn't become a major issue. Overall, this is still a game I'd recommend for a short and sweet game to bat around.

Free as you can see. If you want to help a good cause though, besides the charities listed in the game, buying the DLC would be another purrfect way to send your donation.

74225736.review:
A solid game to support charities. The main levels are a mixture of stealth and collecting gems. Then there are two sets of challenges levels that separate the collecting [1 minute timer to get 250 for platinum rating] and pure stealth. The main levels are pretty easy, and honestly get a bit boring by the last one. But the challenge levels offer a bit more challenge and by the end are more engaging.

I do think the game suffers from camera problems which make stealth a bit annoying at times. Particularly I think level 6, it's a tall tower. That one on the Dogo mode [stealth] is annoying. I ran into invisible floors which made a few parts more difficult. You can walk off certain edges to land on others, but you can't die from walking off ledges. But sometimes you'll walk off to get to something very far down but hit an insivible floor. I had this issue on the last two dogo levels trying to figure out the right way to go. 

But it's free and worth a try. Plus it lists a few animal charities after beating the main levels which is nice.

71715686.review:
Even though I've been caught multiple times just because I couldn't see where I was or where I was going, I LOVE this game. It's everything I've ever wanted in a simple gather stuff game, matched with a fun theme (love cats) that is well rendered. This is one of those games, like Ratchet & Clank, Lego games and others (though not enough games) that has a truly satisfying object acquired sound. 

Salty with the sweet, I intensely dislike when you can't control the volume of the music and in game sound effects separately. While I like the music for this game and many others, in game music often stresses me out . In game sound effects very rarely do though, which is why I prefer the controls for each to be independent of the other.

Though I got this game for free, it's one of the few, like Ratchet and Clank, that developers could have a regular stream of my money from me by adding new levels regularly for a fee. I CAN NOT be the only person that feels this way, yet... we wait for entire new games to be released. Guess what? I'd buy those too and the endless added levels. 

So many developers go after the in game purchases and ignore an entire revenue stress from the people that refuse to spend irl money for in game "items". There HAS to be a sweet spot between how long a level has to be for you to feel satisfied, the money spent for it and the time the company put into creating the level. 

Cat Burglar: A Tail of Purrsuit is one of those games that could get an nearly endless revenue stream from me, either through pay as you go levels or a subscription where every set amount of time I get more content.

Long answer to a short question; Yes, I would recommend this game to other players.

63192502.review:
[h1][b][u]Overall - 80/100[/u][/b][/h1]
This simple, cute little game is crafted with such care, and such heart, that you can't help but love it.

[h1]Playing as a cat - 20/20[/h1]
You play as Kat, a cat burglar who is an actual cat, trying to infiltrate the evil Doggo base.

[h1]Acting like a cat - 10/20[/h1]
The core gameplay mechanic involves avoiding dogs (super cat-like!) and collecting gems/keys (not cat-like at all).

[h1]Adorableness Level - 20/20[/h1]
The in-game cat is cute enough, but this is supplemented with cute drawings in between levels, cute level components, and even cute acheivement names.  The cutest thing is probably that the developers bill it as a "Pet Charity Awareness Game", and show you a different cat charity between each level. 

[h1]Polish - 15/20[/h1]
It's not going to win any design awards, but is put together well enough, and there weren't any issues in gameplay or the menus.

[h1]FUN! - 15/20[/h1]
Think Captain Toad Treasure Tracker, but with stealth, cats, and extra cuteness.  I found myself craving more levels once I was done.

59426667.review:
This is a pretty fun, simple version of a stealth game. It's nothing too complex - you run around levels collecting gems and avoiding guard vision cones as they patrol and turn around, trying to get keys to escape. The difficulty of the levels increases fairly steadily, such that the last levels are a bit challenging, but nothing too difficult if you practice patience and caution.

It's a free game made for charity, so I expected it to be simple or janky, but for what it is it's quite good. My only issue is that the mouse controls were needlessly bad - there's no reason they couldn't have made the camera rotate without needing to constantly hold down the mouse button, and an option to snap the camera to 45-degree increments would have been really helpful. A few of the levels contain "inside" areas that are difficult to see from the orbital perspective, but usually those areas don't have enemies, so they're not too bad.

Overall, this is a cute, fun little stealth game worth an hour or two of your time, and probably worth throwing a few bucks their way for the work they're doing highlighting animal charities!

50333938.review:
[h1] Sly Cooper Meets Toads Treasure Tracker	[/h1]
Just like in Sly Cooper you'll be avoiding spotlights from above as well as the flashlights from the guards. While just like in Toads Treasure Tracker you'll need some fancy camera work and angling to navigate your way through the platforming in these levels. Like a true master thief and cat burglar you'll have to think three steps ahead while navigating watching the guards and lights patterns to map out the best routes to go through as well as a safe stopping point to plan again. If you don't think it through and time it right then you'll most likely just keep getting caught.

As far as controls go you use W A S D to move, and control the camera by holding the left mouse button, unless you use a controller. They recommend a controller, but I think I like it better with keyboard and mouse honestly. That's a personal preference though. The one disappointment I found controls wise is I wish you could jump. I just love having the option even if it serves no game mechanic purpose. It would ruin some of the platforming puzzles if you could jump high making them significantly easier. So maybe if they even put a small jump in so that you wouldn't feel so locked to the ground.

The level design was very good in my opinion it got steadily harder with the exception of level 6 and 7. So like I've said before you have to move around the camera in all directions if you want to find all the keys and gems. It will also help you scope out all the pathways, hidden routes and guard/light patterns. You can't fall off the building to your death, but you can fall to lower floors granted that it's not too long of a drop. You need to be careful though when it comes to the guards flashlights since the ramps and walls won't stop the flashlight's light. It's hard to explain exactly but the cone of light clips through. If you watch the guards pattern you'll see where the light goes as well and how best to avoid it. As I've mentioned the levels get harder with each additional one, adding more depth, layers, guards and lights. The exception being levels 6 and 7. I say that because level 6 was for me unquestionably the hardest level. I got caught an incredible amount of times. Level 7 looks more intimidating if you compare it by looks alone. However while I was caught countless times on level 6, I was only caught once on level 7. I don't think they should be switched though as level 7 looks like it should be the last level.

I also like the heavy charity approach this game takes. As you may have noticed 20% of this games earnings go to an animal charity, along with all the DLCs just being more direct donations to animal charities. Inside the game you even get an achievement for looking at their Charities page in Extras, as well as them showing you an animal charity they support on each winning screen.

It is a very short game, but if you like a challenge or just want to get a game that helps a good cause then this is one of those games. It's all about stealth though and requires a lot of patience on certain levels. I would also like to mention that on your library page if it shows the wrong achievements are locked don't worry it did that for me too. You just have to go to hit the stats button. After you finish the game with all the gems you should have to 100% without a problem.

[h1] Pros:	[/h1]
+Good difficult latter providing a challenge
+Has a good feel to it
+Cute little story
+For charity and provides more resources to donate to
+Can't fall off the map to your death
+option for keyboard and mouse still feels good even though it recommends a controller

[h1] Cons:	[/h1]
-no jumping
-flashlights clip through some walls and ramps
-library achievement page displays the wrong achievements as locked (though they all fill out correctly)

50165888.review:
A game dedicated to animal charity awareness that's also entertaining.
Purchases of this game also have a portion donated to Best Friends, an animal charity group.
The game also sells DLC that are actually developer tips so they can continue to make these kinds of games.
The DLC does not get donated to charity (AFAIK), but is purely for the developers.

The game is very simple: get the keys, get the gems, get out.
Controls are also simple, with no jumping or interaction. Only movement and controlling the camera.
The camera itself is manually controlled, but allows a top-down view for making evading guards and spotlights easier.

The game is very short, featuring 7 levels with about an hour of playtime.
After every level, you are presented with an animal charity and a link to their website or media page.

Overall: A great time for a short play session, and to support charity in the meantime.
+Nice visual style
+Fun gameplay, similar to Captain Toad
+Humorous plot
+Controls well
+-Level 5 and beyond are a tad more difficult than 1-4
-Guard patrols have them do a 180 turn on some levels, and their cone of vision zooms to the side of them for a split second.

45146465.review:
A freeware arcade game that plays well and raises awareness about a ton of great animal care intiatives? This is just awesome! It helps that the game by itself is very fun as well. Also, the puns in the title are equal parts cheesy and adorable.

I usually don't expect much game-wise from PSA games, as long as they drive the message home, but this one is surprisingly good. It is straight-forward, simple, plays well, controls well, and has a very fun core mechanic to it. The music is excellent, I love how there are different songs for each level, and the graphics are cute, albeit a tad on the simpler side.

On the role of a female cat burglar, you must invade multi-layered military bases run by dogs, collect four keys to move on to the next level and, optionally, collect a number of gems that are spread out in every level, all while avoiding being spotted by dogs and cameras. It all works surprisingly well, with solid controls and fair hitboxes (for the most part). As you traverse these fiendish bases, you'll have to move the camera around to see your surroundings and find extra gems and passages to get you out of tight situations, as well as to decide where to drop from ledges to reach collectibles on high places, kinda like, say, that Captain Toad game for the Wii U.

The game is overall very fun to play, simple to understand, but provides little in the way of challenge for experienced gamers. A game like this can't be hard, so I don't mind that there are no super challenges here. It is also pretty short, but that's okay, since it's free.

Outside of that, the framerate occasionally chugs, which is weird since this game looks so simple, but thankfully it's never low enough to break the game flow. Also, it's kind of frustrating to lose all your progress when you make a small mistake and get spotted :(

With all that being said, this is, in general, a very nice little game which brings much needed attention to animal shelters and other animal initiatives while also providing entertaining gameplay. I recommend this to everyone, even people who don't necessarily like this kind of arcade-esque game.

43804634.review:
It's difficult to go wrong with this game. It's free, it has solid controls and graphical quality, it runs quite well and has a tinge of challenge to it (if you go for all of the gems, at least). It has a good artstyle, a cute little narrative and it was made to support animal-based charities, raising awareness of several through the run of the game. There is little that is actually wrong with it and compared to many other free games out there, it does hold a high class.

With that said, it's not perfect. The game is based around avoiding enemies and getting the different keys/gems by generally going to a higher level and then dropping down onto a box or platform. Problem is, there isn't a solid mechanic for dropping, and there is no jumping, so the whole "dropping down" part is a bit awkward. On top of that, a lot of the difficulty comes from pure camera placement, with a lot of the levels being partially or heavily obscured, making it (again), awkward to keep track of everything you need to keep track of.

All in all, it's a nice little game that is good for an hour of entertainment (in its current state at least). If you don't feel like trying it, there is nothing special that you're missing; if you'd like to try it, it will probably entertain you. A harmless bit of fun that I have no problems recommending.

43142032.review:
[i]Relaxing, nostalgic, and addicting.[/i]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
-It brings you back to the time when flash games were good, as it is very flash game-esque and simple.
-All ages can play. There is almost no voices in the game, and all of the language is clean. It is also very simple and extremely easy to understand.
-It supports animals and saves animal lives with charities and charity promotion.
-Relaxing. It is a very soft and laid-back game, as the description implies.
-Great time killer. If you have some spare time on your hands, come back and try to beat that level you were stuck on.
-Simple layout and simple instructions.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
-There isn't any settings (as this review is being written), but they claim to be adding some soon. This means you can't change the video quality, audio, sensitivity, or anything related to the mechanics.
-Can be rage-inducing as it resets the level entirely when you fail.
-It is in a very early stage (as this review as being written), so there will be bugs, glitches, and possibly some errors.
-The levels can get quite repetitive as the mechanics are very simple and the levels are similar in design.

[h1]To conclude:[/h1]
It is a very relaxing and simple game, with lots of potential. It supports animal charities (plenty of them) and is fun and safe for all ages. It is in a very early stage, but with time, I have no doubt this game will gain popularity.

Cat Burglar: A Tail of Purrsuit is a fun, charming stealth game with adorable graphics and really enjoyable music. Each level is a platform puzzle that you navigate your way around, avoiding literal guard dogs, stealing gems and collecting keys to exit the level. 
The game looks great and plays well, the game doesn't have a jump or climb button, but the simple controls combined with the camera rotation make navigation and sneaking up ramps, off ledges and behind guards easy to get used to.

A fun game made by Gamers for Good, to raise awareness of animal charities in need.

42777285.review:
I got this game for free while looking around on Steam for stealth games. I played it on my keyboard, rather than on the intended controller setup, and I don't know if a controller would have made it better, but I found the controls to be a bit too sensitive and while it didn't make the game unplayable, it did make it a little frustrating when I would fall off of the edge of a platform or be caught by a guard. Maybe it's better with a controller. I can't confirm this.
The stealth elements of this game are a little weak, especially the fact that guard lights shine through solid objects, so if a guard shines their light at you hiding behind a box, you'll still be caught, which causes a level restart.
The art is pretty cute, even if the story is nonexistent. There's no memorable music, and the sound effects are stock, but since it's free, I kind of expected that.
Gameplay-wise, it's a little like Captain Toad's Treasure Tracker, but made by an amateur. And considering it was likely made by an amateur, that's sort of to be expected. But considering its price and that I didn't encounter any significant bugs, I enjoyed it for what it was worth, and it's less painful than most free games I've tried. It's also supporting a charity, for a good cause, and the ads for it aren't terribly invasive (they appear on loading screens between levels and not for very long) so I appreciate it from that angle.
If it cost more than a dollar or so, I'd say it's not worth it unless they improve the controls or the stealth elements, but since it's free, I'd say I got enough fun out of it to make it worth a try.

42663903.review:
[h1][Metal Gear Joke Here][/h1]

And that's the only joke I'll be making about this game considering what it is. I usually add a little bit of humor to my reviews of games under the impression that noone will see them and if they do, they may get a small giggle out of it, but I'm writing this review in the hopes that it's noticed by the developers, seeing as they're accepting feedback on this game.

Cat Burglar is a solid game, which is surprising considering the type of effort that normally goes into games like these. I played a few levels and knew I wasn't going to get anything except more of the same but with a surprisingly tight difficulty curve, which is fine by me, but it's definitely a game that has some potential for it to be a neat little casual stealth game to play on the side.

I'm going to now open up all the problems this game has, and then follow up with everything it does right.

Firstly, there's unity based problems this game comes across. Like being able to walk on ledges that would normally shove you off in any other engine. I blame this mainly on the engine, but this is to a degree something that the developers could easily fix by adding some invisible walls to props near the edge of the level, much like how they did to disallow you from falling off the level entirely. 

Another problem is the camera. The layout of levels has the character constantly moving themselves so that the walls come between the camera and the character. This is mitigated slightly by the character's silhouette appearing over the wall where the character should be, much like Super Mario Sunshine's sewer segments. This would be great if the same effect were given to patrolling enemies as well.

The patrol themselves are also somewhat unfair. Theoretically, they can see you through walls, as their viewcone is simply that. A cone. It's not quite an advanced sensor. It's also pretty funny to see their viewsight move over a ledge and act as if they're looking at a flat floor. An easy fix is strangely enough readily available to the developers, as they could probably use the same code that comes from the rotating spotlights, which work much like a spotlight should. Whether this may possibly cause balancing issues is yet to be seen.

The sound design is iffy. The only sounds you get are when you pick up gems or keys, and the music that plays in the background (and getting captured too, I suppose). The music doesn't loop nicely either. I'd like to hear Kat's footsteps while she walks around, and maybe the dog patrols sniffing around while they stand still when Kat gets close to them. Little things like that to fill up the strange silence.

Another thing that could use some work is the animations. Mainly just... Blinking. Everything else flows nicely but Kat's eyes... They stare into the soul. Maybe have her eyes look around, much like Link from WindWaker would do. The dogs are fine animation wise, as their eyes are covered up, but little details really add up in making a good game, so maybe adding some idle animations to them beyond just looking around. Maybe they're biting on the bone they carry around with them when noone's looking. Again, it's the little things that add up.

There's also a lack of things to do. The variety of puzzles consists of looking around the map for gems and keys, figuring out that you have to climb to a higher platform and drop down from it to pick up the collectibles, and then move on your merry way, avoiding guards and the likes. While this alone does work well and can be rearranged in a number of ways, it doesn't offer much in terms of engagement with the player.

Lastly, the game likes to place an advertisement for the multiple charities they endorse. While it's nice that they made this game for the sake of publicizing these charities, it might be better if they shoved that somewhere near the end, before the credits play, and maybe instead of hiding it away in the extra's menu, they could make it their selection in the main menu to bring it more to the forefront without breaking up gameplay in a somewhat strange way. This critique is almost entirely a personal thing for me though so don't take this as a definitive negative to your game.

Like I said, the game is solid considering it's a charity game. It's got enough in it to keep you entertained if you like playing casual games and the aesthetic is pleasant to look at. It also helps that it's an above average unity game featuring it's own assets. It has a potential to be pretty great, and I hope that the developers take the time to think this game through before releasing it out of early access as is.

Overall I give it my very own personally created award of [b]"Yep, that's a game alright!"[/b] and rate it a solid [b]Tactical Catspionage Action/This is my longest review as of the time of writing this[/b]

The goal was to make a very simple charity game with zero budget so we can give it away for free. :)

42649328.review:
Cat Burglar : A Tail of Purrsuit, is a 3D platformer puzzle. In the game, you play as a Cat Burglar trying to steal gems from the Dogs and then escaping. The objective is to try to collect all 50 gems in a level and get 4 cat keys to open the final door. There are only 7 levels and if you get caught, you have to repeat the level from the start.

Gameplaywise, it's just the WASD keys for movement and the mouse for rotating the view. The mouse is essential as you cannot jump, climb or rotate the view on your own. All movement only involves walking and falling to a lower level. In order to find all the keys and gems, you have to rotate the view to deduce a suitable path to the reward. On each stage, there will be guard dogs and search lights. Avoid the search zone or you will fail the level. If and after you complete each stage, you will be given an image of a pet shelter notifying you of how you can help.

Conclusion, do try this game. It's free and it's for a good cause involving pet shelters.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. It's Free
Yes, really free. The only cost is the ad at the end of every level and those are for charity.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. The View
While this is part of the gameplay, it's annoying to not be able to see the hidden diamonds and keys.

42538028.review:
Cat Burglar: A Tail of Purrsuit.

Is it good? No
Is it Bad?   No

Summary.
It's not a bad game just somewhat forgettable and the design can be a bit tedious. It needs adjustment to feel like an actual game and reduce repetitive action. Incorporate more elements about charity and more things to do. As changes come along and new elements are rolled out I would love to be able to update my review and change my reccomendation.


What works in Cat Burglar?
-Charity is a moral candy bar, a charity for cats and dogs is like moral Girl Scout cookies.
-Showing the player various web sites and charity orignizations for animals is a positive cinsidering I wasn't actually 
  expecting to have it mentioned in the game. 

What fell flat with Cat Burglar?
-I missed the tutorial, it didn't stand out enough from the environment. Perhaps adding a glowing silhouette to the instructional boards would draw better player attention.
-Unbind space bar from the paws menu, there were several instances of accidentally hitting it and one that resulted in lost progress.
-Having free motion camera controls actually hinders the player experience, too much time is spent fidgeting with the right angle and results in mission failure. Perhaps a system similar to FEZ with fixed camera angle that the player can rotate between would be more appropriate.
-The game doesnt seem to actually have anything to do with animal charity other than having animals in it and an abrasive series of ads for various charity groups between each level. It would assist the games purpose if the charity information as well as the message of helping animals was more directly related to gameplay. Perhaps find and free various abused animals hidden in each level and have a series of unlockable posters or decorations about charity for a hideout that the player could customize. 
-It's kind of boring. To be honest I gave up on level 5 of 7 because it's lackluster and tedious. More of just about anything would have helped and being that it is early access I hope more jem types and objectives get added along with more levels of varying locations and environments.

-BUGS
  1. Level 4-Rear stairwell.
      I discovered that flashlights can in fact see you even if you are below the projected light cone. how far below remains a mystery.
  2. Silhouette does not show up through all of the walls, there was a decorative banner on an exterior wall and it actually completely hid my outline from view.

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/]Follow our curator page: [b]IndieGems[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

Cat Burglar: A Tail of Purrsuit is a fantastic 3-D stealth puzzle platformer created by [b]Gamers for Good[/b] in order to raise pet charity awareness. The game is free and fantastic, so why not go try it out!

This game says it is in Early Access, but so far the levels feel polished and fun, better than a lot of the cheap shovelware out there.

You play as Kat, and you need to infiltrate the Dogo base, collecting gems along the way, as well as 4 keys in order to get past each level's main door. Good thing the Dogo Corps leader, Major Bull, decided to leave these gems everywhere so that he can catch you red-handed. Each level you complete shows a pet charity, and tells you how you can help out.

This is a good platforming game, it is short and sweet. The controls are responsive--only movement and camera controls. The game can be played with keyboard/mouse or controller. You can zoom in and out and move the camera around, which is crucial in some areas to avoid Dogo detection!

The graphics are good and polished, the small cartoon segments and the design of the levels are pretty nice too. Some really goofy and cute parts too!

The music is really cheerful and fun, the sound effects are simple and nice.

Seriously though, this is a fun little game that is well designed and feels polished. It is free and for a good cause. Please everyone, go check it out!

42514626.review:
Fun little puzzle platformer stealth game.

The gameplay is pretty simple, you control a cat that can only walk (you can't jump). You have to walk around collecting gems and keys while avoiding dogs. It's relatively easy, you simply have to turn the camera around to make sure you see where you are going and avoid the lights.

The levels are well designed and the art style is beautiful. The music is good although a little repetitive and there is currently no option to turn it off or change the volume.

Even though the game is pretty easy, it's also really unforgiving, which makes it more and more stressful as you progress in a level because you know that if you get caught you'll have to start back at the start of the level and you'll lose everything you've collected, which can be as much as 100 gems and 4 keys.

The game is currently in Early Access, but the levels feel like a finished product. The only problems I've has was one of the dogs path that made it go through a wall in a corner, and also when you fall of an edge, it's sometimes a little difficult to control so one time I fell a little further than I should have and got caught.

The game is free and has a publicity for a charity between each level If you're worried it might be annoying to have a publicity between levels, know that it's only there for 2-3 seconds, and it's only an image and now a video, so it's really not a problem.

The Early Access version currently has 7 levels, more should be added later, and it took me about 50 minutes to complete.
